Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible in

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnart

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, a

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and began in a time when injury in dail

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, a

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sp

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, inc

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For exampl

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive stranded mountain climbers

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thou

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public ser

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and resue worker funds

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retreive stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and resue worker funds, and can be dangerous fo rth

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous fo rthe rescu workers as well.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in t

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traff

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a natural

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction insident

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, etc. And those are far m

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, etc. And those are far more common, as far more pe

And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fietc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught ietc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive,

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangr

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous.

 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered n

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, even though o

Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, even though often they are luxuri

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, even though oft

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.

For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Final

And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme spo

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like wit

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky ov

Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, a

But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measi

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measir

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measures are developed, the dangers will decrease. And it would be

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measures are developed, the dangers will decrease. And it would be sad to lose such ex

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous. 

Some people might say that the cost of these sports is passed on to others, including people with no interest in the sport. For example a rescue mission to retrieve stranded mountain climbers can costs thousands and thousands of dollar of public service and rescue worker funds, and can be dangerous for the rescue workers as well.  But the same is true in the case of a terrible traffic accident, or a construction incident, fishing boats caught in storms etc. And those are far more common, as far more people choose to drive, or work dangerous jobs. But those things are considered necessary, and so the risk is ignored. 

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measures are developed, the dangers will decrease. And it would be sad to lose such exciting and enjoyabl

Finally, while extreme sports are risky, like with any activity they will become less risky over time. As more is learned about them, and more safety measures are developed, the dangers will decrease. And it would be sad to lose such exciting and enjoyable activities due to

Is It Selfish to Pursue Risky Sports Like Extreme Mountain Climbing?

Some sports, like extreme mountain climbing, are dangerous. Since there are varying degrees of risk in most, if not all, sports (such as the possibility of concussions, broken bones and even death), how does one decide where the line might be drawn between what is reasonable and what is not? Are some sports simply too dangerous to be called a sport?

---

In my opinion, extreme sport are not to dangerous to be sports. Of course there needs to be some restrictions on them - mountains should be closed of the conditions are dangerous, same with surfing areas, skateparks should be inspected for structural safety, etc. But it is a personal risk which one chooses to do, and that personal choice should remain once all reasonable precautions have been taken.
But generally, sports are about testing yourself.
 All sports can result in terrible injury; think about all the recent controversies recently around concussions especially in football and soccer. And all of the terrible, literally bone shattering, injuries that happen in gymnastics. And yet we allow it, or at least don't prevent it - why? Because those sports are traditional ones, and we have long since become accustomed to the dangers of them. But most extreme sports are new, and from the comparison, seem more dangerous.
